STEVE AUSTIN:

Prime Minister Tony Abbott is in Queensland at the moment. I saw him on ABC TV News 24 with the representative of Bravehearts down on the Gold Coast. Prime Minister, good morning to you.

STEVE AUSTIN:

PRIME MINISTER:

STEVE AUSTIN:

Richard Mulcahy told me that some of the supermarket chains have been working with suppliers from overseas to improve their standards but they have major issues of poverty and water quality. PRIME MINISTER:

This isnât just a matter for government, Steve. STEVE AUSTIN:

Richard Mulcahy pointed out youâve been talking about improving labelling for nine years. Many Australians apparently want you to just do it. PRIME MINISTER:

STEVE AUSTIN:

PRIME MINISTER:

STEVE AUSTIN:

PRIME MINISTER:

But itâs very important that government makes things better, not worse, and the last thing I want to do is put a whole lot of additional requirements on business that will make their life very, very difficult and which will raise unreasonably prices to consumers, because everything that we do in this area has a cost. Now, some price is worth paying â I absolutely accept that â but itâs got to be a careful balancing act. Careful judgement has to be applied here. Now, I know thereâs a parliamentaryâ¦

STEVE AUSTIN:

PRIME MINISTER:

No, we will do our jobs, and at the moment thereâs a body called FSANZ â Food Standards Australia New Zealand. Itâs a joint Commonwealth, state, New Zealand body. It decides whether a product is high-risk and if itâs high-risk thereâs 100 per cent screening, if itâs low-risk thereâs surveillance which is five per cent screening. So, Iâm certainly very happy to see FSANZ have another look at things like the screening of berries from overseas â very happy for that to happen â but, in the end, itâs always got to be a question of judgement, Steve. Itâs always got to be a question of getting the balance right, because every time we demand more regulation, every time we demand different kinds of labelling, we add the costs and the consumer has to pay. Now, Iâve got to respect consumersâ pockets; Iâve got to respect their financial health as well as other aspects of their health.

STEVE AUSTIN:

Iâm speaking with the Prime Minister of Australia Tony Abbott. In the couple of minutes Iâve got left, Prime Minister, Iâd like to ask you about the outcome of the Queensland state election. Many on the LNP side of politics blamed you and your public statements for damaging the brand of the LNP, if you like, in the lead up to the state election and I donât believe you had a chance to respond to that. Particularly, former deputy premier, Jeff Seeney, very clearly pointed the finger at you and, to a lesser extent, Bruce McIver. Were you responsible in any way for the loss of the LNP in the last state election?

PRIME MINISTER:

Obviously, the Liberal and National parties are a family right around Australia and if we go badly in one area, it has an impact on other areas; conversely, if we go well in one area, it has an impact in other areas. And look, I spoke regularly with Campbell Newman throughout the campaign. Campbell is a friend of mine. I deeply regret the outcome and his considered opinion to me in the days after the election was that it was overwhelmingly fought on state issues.

Now, as far as the Commonwealth is concerned, obviously, we are always trying to learn the right lessons from whatâs happening around our country, but in terms of Queensland, this Commonwealth Government â this Coalition Government in Canberra â weâve scrapped the carbon tax, weâve scrapped the mining tax. Weâve committed $700 million to the Toowoomba Range crossing and now, my anxiety is that a new government â a new government that didnât have access to the resources that the Newman Government did â wonât be able to go ahead with some of these things.

STEVE AUSTIN:

Prime Minister, good to speak with you. Thank you very much.
